essays.prompt: Some students have a background, identity, interest, or talent that …
The lessons we take from obstacles we encounter can be fundamental to later success.
Reflect on a time when you questioned or challenged a belief or idea.
Reflect on something that someone has done for you that has made you happy or thankful in a surprising way.
Discuss an accomplishment, event, or realization that sparked a period of personal growth.
Describe a topic, idea, or concept you find so engaging that it makes you lose track of time.
Share an essay on any topic of your choice.
How will the life experiences that shape who you are today enable you to contribute to Harvard?
Describe a time when you strongly disagreed with someone about an idea or issue. How did you communicate or engage with this person? What did you learn?
Briefly describe any extracurricular activities, employment experience, travel, or family responsibilities that have shaped who you are.
How do you hope to use your Harvard education in the future?
What would your future roommates like to know about you?
What is the most significant challenge that society faces today?
How did you spend your last two summers?
What historical moment or event would you like to have witnessed?
Elaborate on one of your extracurricular activities, a job, or responsibility.
List five things that are important to you.
Reflect on an idea or experience that makes you genuinely excited about learning.
Write a note to your future roommate that reveals something about you.
Describe what aspects of your life, interests, and character would help you make a distinctive contribution as an undergraduate.
What field of study appeals to you the most right now? Tell us why it appeals to you at MIT.
Tell us about something you do simply for the pleasure of it.
In what ways have you done something different than expected in your educational journey?
Describe one way you have collaborated with others to learn from them or contribute together.
How did you manage a situation or challenge you didn’t expect? What did you learn?
Reflect on a time you discussed an issue important to you with someone holding an opposing view. Why was it meaningful?
Reflect on your membership in a community to which you feel connected. Why is this community meaningful to you?
Reflect on an element of your personal experience that you feel will enrich your college.
Tell us about a community you are part of and why it matters to you.
Explain your commitment to civic engagement or service in your community.
What is a new skill you would like to learn in college?
What brings you joy?
What song represents the soundtrack of your life at this moment?
List the resources (books, professors, communities, etc.) that have most influenced your intellectual development.
Tell us about an aspect of your perspective or experience that is important to you and how it would contribute to Columbia.
What attracts you to your preferred areas of study at Columbia?
Why Columbia? Why do you want to study at Columbia specifically?
Write a short thank-you note to someone you haven’t thanked yet and would like to acknowledge.
Describe your commitment to service or community engagement.
What are your long-term career goals and how does equity factor into them?
What three words best describe you?
What is your most meaningful extracurricular commitment and what should we know about it?
If you could teach a class on any topic, what would it be?
In one sentence, why Brown?
